summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing a court-ordered declaration to explain disparities in discovery and counsel access between detainees Ghislaine Maxwell and Justin Rivera. It details the differences in their housing situations and the resulting accommodations, addressing concerns raised by Judge Engelmayer about potential unequal treatment.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Detained at the MDC in protective custody, receiving extensive accommodations for discovery review (13 hours/day) and counsel visits (15 hours/week) due to her unique housing situation and case complexity.

persons.name: Justin Rivera
persons.context: Detained at the MCC in general population, charged with sex trafficking conspiracy; his counsel raised concerns about inferior discovery and counsel access compared to Maxwell, prompting judicial inquiry.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Presiding over United States v. Rivera et al.; expressed frustration with MCC's treatment of Rivera, noted 'terrible' optics in disparity with Maxwell's access, and ordered a BOP declaration to explain the differences.

connections.description: Both are federal detainees whose access to discovery and counsel accommodations are being compared by the court, with Maxwell receiving significantly more access due to different housing and case circumstances.
Judge Engelmayer is overseeing Rivera's case, has issued orders for accommodations, and demanded an explanation from prosecutors regarding disparities in treatment compared to Maxwell.

events.title: Deadline for BOP Declaration
events.description: Court-ordered deadline for the U.S. Attorney's Office to submit a declaration from the Bureau of Prisons explaining the disparities in discovery and counsel access between Maxwell and Rivera.

events.title: Finalization of Response on Disparities
events.description: Prosecutors finalized their response explaining that differences in accommodations stem from case-specific factors, housing situations, and facility logistics.

events.title: Judge Engelmayer's Inquiry on Disparities
events.description: Defense counsel in Rivera's case raised concerns about unequal treatment compared to Maxwell, prompting Judge Engelmayer to request a formal explanation from the government.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for Justin Rivera
events.description: Rivera's sex trafficking trial was expected to begin on this date (note: year is likely 2021 per context, but text states 2020).

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was housed in protective custody at the MDC with sole access to a room for 13 hours daily for discovery review, while Justin Rivera was in general population at the MCC sharing facilities with about 80 other inmates.
Judge Engelmayer described the disparity in access between Maxwell and Rivera as 'terrible' optics and suggested it could be perceived as based on race, gender, and class.

The government's explanation attributes the disparity to Maxwell's case having 'multiple times more discovery,' her unique protective custody housing, and different facility capabilities at MDC versus MCC.

By late December 2020, the MCC began leaving a laptop with Rivera all day for charging, effectively matching Maxwell's electronic discovery access, though VTC access remained limited due to shared inmate resources.
The email chain reveals internal coordination at the U.S. Attorney's Office to draft declarations from BOP associate wardens to satisfy the court's deadline of December 31, 2020.
